â
'''Microsoft Security Essentials (MSE)''' (previously [[List of Microsoft codenames|codenamed]] '''Morro''') is a [[freeware|free]] [[antivirus software]] created by [[Microsoft]] that provides protection against [[Computer virus|viruses]], [[spyware]], [[rootkit]]s, and [[Trojan horse (computing)|trojans]] for [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], and [[Windows 7|7]].<ref name="Reuters" >Finkle, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/CMPTRS/idUSN1044924620090610 "Update 3-Microsoft will soon unveil free anti-virus software"], [[Thomson Reuters]], June 10, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> MSE replaces [[Windows Live OneCare]] (a subscription antivirus service) and [[Windows Defender]], which only protects users from [[adware]] and [[spyware]].<ref name="SuperSite" >Thurrott, Paul. [http://www.winsupersite.com/win7/mse_beta.asp "Microsoft Security Essentials Public Beta"], Paul Thurrott's SuperSite for Windows, June 18, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> It is geared for home use, unlike Microsoft's upcoming enterprise-oriented product [[Microsoft Forefront]].
+
'''Microsoft Security Essentials (MSE)''' (previously [[List of Microsoft codenames|codenamed]] '''Morro''') is a [[gratis]] [[antivirus software]] created by [[Microsoft]] that provides protection against [[Computer virus|viruses]], [[spyware]], [[rootkit]]s, and [[Trojan horse (computing)|trojans]] for [[Windows XP]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], and [[Windows 7|7]].<ref name="Reuters" >Finkle, Jim. [http://www.reuters.com/article/CMPTRS/idUSN1044924620090610 "Update 3-Microsoft will soon unveil free anti-virus software"], [[Thomson Reuters]], June 10, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> MSE replaces [[Windows Live OneCare]] (a subscription antivirus service) and [[Windows Defender]], which only protects users from [[adware]] and [[spyware]].<ref name="SuperSite" >Thurrott, Paul. [http://www.winsupersite.com/win7/mse_beta.asp "Microsoft Security Essentials Public Beta"], Paul Thurrott's SuperSite for Windows, June 18, 2009, accessed July 4, 2009.</ref> It is geared for home use, unlike Microsoft's upcoming enterprise-oriented product [[Microsoft Forefront]].
â
[[Symantec]] and [[McAfee]], two competing antivirus vendors, responded by claiming that MSE is not comparable with their own offerings.<ref>Keizer, Gregg. [http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9138667/Rivals_mock_Microsoft_s_free_security_software "Rivals mock Microsoft's free security software"] [[Computerworld]], September 29, 2009, accessed September 30, 2009.</ref> [[AVG Technologies]] viewed MSE positively, stating it reinforced the company's ideal of free antivirus software. Reviews were mostly positive, citing its organized interface, low resource usage, and [[Freeware]].<ref name="Ars Technica" >Protalinski, Emil. [http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/09/first-look-microsoft-security-essentials-impresses.ars "First look: Microsoft Security Essentials impresses"], [[Ars Technica]], September 29, 2009, accessed September 30, 2009.</ref>
+
[[Symantec]] and [[McAfee]], two competing antivirus vendors, responded by claiming that MSE is not comparable with their own offerings.<ref>Keizer, Gregg. [http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9138667/Rivals_mock_Microsoft_s_free_security_software "Rivals mock Microsoft's free security software"] [[Computerworld]], September 29, 2009, accessed September 30, 2009.</ref> [[AVG Technologies]] viewed MSE positively, stating it reinforced the company's ideal of free antivirus software. Reviews were mostly positive, citing its organized interface, low resource usage, and the fact that it is free/gratis.<ref name="Ars Technica" >Protalinski, Emil. [http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/09/first-look-microsoft-security-essentials-impresses.ars "First look: Microsoft Security Essentials impresses"], [[Ars Technica]], September 29, 2009, accessed September 30, 2009.</ref>
